question.text: (CBSE 2023) Sound cannot travel through:
question.explanation: Sound requires material medium (solid, liquid, gas) for propagation. Vacuum has no particles to vibrate.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) The number of oscillations per second is called:
question.explanation: Frequency (f) = oscillations per second. SI unit: Hertz (Hz). Human range: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz.

question.text: (CBSE 2022) The speed of sound is maximum in:
question.explanation: Sound speed: Solids > Liquids > Gases. Steel: ~5000 m/s, Water: ~1500 m/s, Air: ~330 m/s, Vacuum: 0.

question.text: (SEBA 2022) Loudness of sound depends on:
question.explanation: Loudness ∝ amplitude². Greater amplitude → louder sound. Measured in decibels (dB).

question.text: (CBSE 2021) The unit of frequency is:
question.explanation: 1 Hertz = 1 oscillation per second. Named after Heinrich Hertz. 1 kHz = 1000 Hz.

question.text: (SEBA 2021) The characteristic that distinguishes two sounds of same loudness and pitch is:
question.explanation: Timbre (quality) helps identify source (e.g., same note on guitar vs piano). Due to overtones/harmonics.

question.text: (CBSE 2020) The hearing range of human ear is:
question.explanation: Audible range: 20 Hz (infrasound) to 20,000 Hz (ultrasound). Decreases with age, especially high frequencies.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) The persistence of sound due to repeated reflection is:
question.explanation: Reverberation: sound persists (multiple reflections). Echo: distinct reflection heard separately (>0.1 s delay).

question.text: (CBSE 2019) Which phenomenon explains twinkling of stars?
question.explanation: Atmospheric refraction: starlight bends due to varying air density → apparent position changes → twinkling.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) Pitch of sound depends on:
question.explanation: Pitch (shrillness) ∝ frequency. Higher frequency → higher pitch (female voice). Lower frequency → lower pitch (male voice).

question.text: (CBSE 2018) SONAR works on principle of:
question.explanation: SONAR (Sound Navigation And Ranging): emits ultrasound, detects echo to measure depth/locate objects.

question.text: (SEBA 2018) The speed of sound in air at 20°C is approximately:
question.explanation: In dry air at 20°C: 343 m/s, often taken as 340 m/s. Increases with temperature: v ∝ √T.

question.text: Sound is produced by:
question.explanation: Vibrating object causes medium particles to vibrate → compressions & rarefactions → sound wave.

question.text: The time taken for one complete oscillation is:
question.explanation: Time period (T) = 1/f. Unit: second (s). Example: f = 50 Hz → T = 0.02 s.

question.text: Which part of human ear converts sound vibrations to electrical signals?
question.explanation: Cochlea (inner ear) has hair cells that convert vibrations to nerve impulses → auditory nerve → brain.

question.text: Ultrasound has frequency:
question.explanation: Ultrasound: >20 kHz (beyond human hearing). Uses: medical imaging, cleaning, SONAR. Infrasound: <20 Hz.

question.text: Sound travels as:
question.explanation: Sound wave: longitudinal (particles vibrate parallel to wave direction). Light: transverse (perpendicular).

question.text: The distance between two consecutive compressions is:
question.explanation: Wavelength (λ) = distance between successive compressions or rarefactions. v = fλ.

question.text: Why can't we hear sound on moon?
question.explanation: Moon has near vacuum → no medium for sound propagation. Astronauts use radio communication.

question.text: Bats navigate using:
question.explanation: Bats emit ultrasound clicks, detect echoes to locate prey/obstacles. Dolphins also use echolocation.

question.text: The unit of loudness is:
question.explanation: Loudness measured in decibels (dB). Normal conversation: ~60 dB, Pain threshold: ~120 dB, Whisper: ~30 dB.

question.text: An echo is heard when distance between source and obstacle is at least: (v=340 m/s)
question.explanation: Minimum distance for distinct echo: d = v×t/2 = 340×0.1/2 = 17 m (t=0.1 s for persistence of hearing).

question.text: Which property distinguishes musical sound from noise?
question.explanation: Musical sound: regular, pleasing. Noise: irregular, unpleasant. Both have loudness, pitch, timbre but pattern differs.

question.text: The sound of frequency 25 Hz is:
question.explanation: 25 Hz > 20 Hz → audible (low frequency). Infrasonic: <20 Hz. Ultrasound: >20,000 Hz.

question.text: In which medium does sound travel fastest at same temperature?
question.explanation: Speed: solids > liquids > gases. Iron ~5000 m/s > water ~1500 m/s > gases ~300-500 m/s.

question.text: The reflection of sound is used in:
question.explanation: All use reflection to direct/amplify sound. Stethoscope: chest sounds, Megaphone: direct voice, Soundboard: in auditoriums.

question.text: If frequency of sound is doubled, its wavelength:
question.explanation: v = fλ (constant in same medium). f → 2f → λ → λ/2 to keep v constant.

question.text: The range of infrasound is:
question.explanation: Infrasound: <20 Hz. Produced by earthquakes, volcanoes, elephants, whales. Can travel long distances.

question.text: Loudness is proportional to:
question.explanation: Loudness ∝ (amplitude)². Double amplitude → 4× loudness. Also depends on sensitivity of ear.

question.text: Sound waves in air are:
question.explanation: Mechanical waves require medium. Electromagnetic waves (light, radio) can travel through vacuum.

question.text: The ceiling of concert halls are curved to:
question.explanation: Curved ceilings distribute sound evenly, reduce excessive reverberation for clarity.

question.text: A child hears an echo 2 seconds after shouting near cliff. Distance to cliff is: (v=340 m/s)
question.explanation: Distance = v×t/2 = 340×2/2 = 340 m. Sound travels to cliff and back (2× distance).

question.text: The part that vibrates in human voice box is:
question.explanation: Voice box (larynx) contains vocal cords that vibrate when air passes → sound. Pitch controlled by tension.

question.text: Shock waves are produced by objects moving:
question.explanation: Supersonic speed (>340 m/s) creates shock waves → sonic boom. Example: jet aircraft, bullet.

question.text: The speed of sound increases with:
question.explanation: v ∝ √T (absolute temperature). In air: v = 331 + 0.6t m/s (t in °C). Humidity slightly increases speed.

question.text: Which instrument measures sound intensity?
question.explanation: Sound level meter measures dB. Audiometer tests hearing. Oscilloscope displays waveforms.

question.text: The full form of SONAR is:
question.explanation: SONAR uses ultrasound for underwater detection, mapping, communication.

question.text: A tuning fork produces sound due to:
question.explanation: When struck, prongs vibrate at natural frequency → produces pure tone of specific frequency.

question.text: Noise pollution can cause:
question.explanation: Noise above 85 dB can cause permanent hearing damage, stress, high BP, sleep issues.

question.text: The audible range for dogs is up to:
question.explanation: Dogs hear ultrasound up to ~45 kHz. Dog whistles use ~20-30 kHz (inaudible to humans).

question.text: When sound passes from air to water, which changes?
question.explanation: Frequency (pitch) remains same. Speed increases in water → wavelength increases (v = fλ).
